facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 127 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 127 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 12th February 1957 of Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th February, 1957, of the Madras High Court in Crimi- nal Appeal No. 728 of 1956 and Referred Trial No. 144 of 1956,

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment arose from trial court judgment dated 23rd October 1956.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 23rd October, 1956, of the Court of the Addl. Sessions Judge of the Coimbatore Division in S. C. Nos. 120 135 of 1956.

facts.text: Four accused tried before Additional Sessions Judge of Coimbatore Division.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Additional Judge of the companyrt of Sessions of Coimbatore Division there were four accused, of whom the first accused Subramania Goundan has number appealed

facts.text: First accused Subramania Goundan is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: of whom the first accused Subramania Goundan has number appealed to this companyrt against the companyfirmation by the High Court

facts.text: Second accused Marappa Goundan was father of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Along with the appellant were tried three others, of whom the second accused  Marappa Goundan  was his father.

facts.text: Appellant convicted and sentenced to death on charges 1 and 2, rigorous imprisonment for two years on charge 3.

anchor.surface_text: against the companyfirmation by the High Court of Madras of the companyviction and sentence by the trial companyrt, by which, on charges Nos. 1 2, he was sentenced to death, and also sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for two years on charge No. 3.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on 6th May 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Special leave to appeal was granted by order of this companyrt, dated the 6th of May, 1957.

facts.text: Charges: Appellant murdered Marappa Goundan by cutting with aruval on night June 6 1956 at Vengakalpalayam.

anchor.surface_text: the first was against the appellant, that he on June 6, 1956, at night in the Village of Vengakalpalayam, companymitted the murder of Marappa Goundan by cutting him with an aruval

facts.text: Second charge: Appellant murdered Muthu Goundan by stabbing with spear same time and place.

anchor.surface_text: while the second charge was that at about the same time and place and in the companyrse of the same transaction, he companymit- ted the murder of Muthu Goundan by stabbing him with a spear.

facts.text: Village Vengakalpalayam was faction-ridden; appellant and father one side, deceased and Munia Goundan rival faction.

anchor.surface_text: The village, where the offences were companymitted, was faction- ridden in which the appellant, his father and others took one side, whereas the two deceased individuals along with Munia Goundan

facts.text: Appellant's father was leading man of village.

anchor.surface_text: and others, former the leaders of the rival faction. It was also stated that the appellants father was the leading man of the village,

facts.text: Three days prior to occurrence on night 6-7 June 1956, Munia Goundan threatened to wipe out appellant's father or shave his moustache.

anchor.surface_text: About three days prior to the occurrence, which took place on the night between the 6th and the 7th of June, 1956, Munia Goundan is said to have stated to the hearing of the appel- lant

facts.text: Appellant armed with aruval, spear, knife left house on night 6-7 June 1956, attacked Marappa Goundan in field-shed at Chettithottam.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, according to the prosecution, having armed himself with an aruval  a sickle  a spear and a knife left his house on the night of the 6th and 7th June, 1956, proceeded to a place known as Chettithottam

facts.text: Appellant cut Marappa Goundan on neck with aruval and inflicted other injuries.

anchor.surface_text: where the de- ceased Marappa Goundan was sleeping in his field-shed, and cut him on the neck with the aruval, and inflicted other injuries on him before leaving the place.

facts.text: Appellant stabbed Muthu Goundan with spear on way to Munia Goundan's house.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter while on his way to the house of Munia Goundan to do away with him, the appellant met the deceased Muthu Goundan who was companying in the opposite direction

facts.text: Appellant stabbed Munia Goundan (PW5) at his house.

anchor.surface_text: After this the appellant went to the house of Munia Goundan  P. W. 5  and stabbed him also.

facts.text: Appellant set fire to shed of Sennimalai Goundan (PW4) four furlongs away.

anchor.surface_text: Not being companytent with companymitting these crimes, he set fire to the shed of Sennimalai Goundan  P. W. 4-who was also a partisan of the rival faction  which lay at a distance about four furlongs

facts.text: Report given to village Munsif at 5 a.m. on 7-6-1956 by PW1 and PW4.

anchor.surface_text: went to the house of the village Munsif who was living about four miles away from the village and gave a report about the occurrence at about 5 a.m. on 7-6- 1956 and which is on record as Exhibit P.I.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector of Police (PW17) received information at 8:30 a.m., reached scene at 11 a.m. on 7 June 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Information reached the Sub-Inspector of Police of Avanashi  P.W.17  at 8-30 a.m. who reached the place of occurrence at 11 a.m.

facts.text: Appellant arrested at 12 noon near temple on 7 June 1956.

anchor.surface_text: At about 12 numbern near a temple in the village finding the appellant there, the SubInspector of Police arrested him

facts.text: Bloodstained drawer (MO10) and baniyan (MO11) seized from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: From the appellant material objects Nos. 10 and 11, a bloodstained drawer and a baniyan respectively worn by him were seized

facts.text: Bloodstained bed-sheet (MO12) recovered from appellant's garden shed.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant thereafter took the Police Officer to his garden and took out M. 0. 12, a blood-stained bed-sheet from a rafter in the garden shed

facts.text: Appellant produced before Magistrate PW7 on June 9 1956 at 3:50 p.m., given time for reflection till June 11.

anchor.surface_text: On June 9, 1956, at about 3-50 p.m. the appellant was pro- duced before Sri P. I. Veeraswami, Sub-Magistrate  P. W. 7 , who administered the necessary warnings under the Crimi- nal Rules of Practice

facts.text: Appellant made confessional statement on June 11 1956 before Magistrate, exhibited as P.3/A.

anchor.surface_text: on-which date the appellant was produced before the same Magistrate at 3-50 p.m. ... This statement in which the appellant companyfessed to having companymitted the murder of Marappa Goundan and Muthu Goundan

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted accused 2,3,4 but convicted appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge acquitted accused Nos. 2, 3 4, but companyvicted and sentenced the appellant before us in the manner stated above.

facts.text: High Court did not rely on oral testimony of PW5, PW10, PW11 but upheld conviction on retracted confession.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court Somasundaram J. ... was number inclined to place reliance on the oral testimony of P.W. 5, P.W10 and W. 1 1. ... but the learned judge upheld the companyviction on the ground that as the companyfession was voluntary and true

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 17 1957 by Govinda Menon J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 17. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GOVINDA MENON J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held confession voluntary, true, corroborated by recoveries with human blood, upheld conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Agreeing with the High Court that this is companyroboration of the companyfession made by the appel- lant, we are of the opinion that the companyfession can be acted upon. If that is so, the appellants guilt has been proved beyond reasonable doubt.

facts.text: Chemical Examiner report showed human blood on MO10,11,12.

anchor.surface_text: the presence of human-blood on material objects Nos. 10, 11 12, it follows that the blood of the murdered was on these material objects.

issues.text: whether the High Court erred in law in agreeing with the trial court regarding the guilt of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, before us is whether the High Court erred in law in agreeing with the trial court regarding the guilt of the appellant. Had the High Court come to the conclusion that the evidence of P.Ws. 5, 10 11 can be accepted in order to sustain the conviction of the appellant, the question would have been simpler of solution,

issues.text: whether the confession, Ex. P. 3/A, is entitled to credence and be acted upon

anchor.surface_text: The ultimate approach, therefore, to the question should be whether the confession, Ex. P. 3/A, is entitled to credence and be acted upon. The learned counsel for the appellant, Sri Umrigar, was at pains to show, firstly that the confession was not voluntary secondly it is not true and lastly that even if these two tests are answered in the affirmative so far as the prosecution is concerned,

firstly that the confession was not voluntary secondly it is not true and lastly that even if these two tests are answered in the affirmative so far as the prosecution is concerned, it would be very unsafe to act on this retracted confession which, according to him, was resiled from as early as an opportunity occurred. Dealing with the first question,

The second aspect of the learned counsel's contention is that the confession is not true. In Sarawan Singh and Harbans Singh v, The State of Punjab 1 this court expressed the opinion that for the purpose of finding out whether a confession is true, it would be necessary to examine the same and compare it with the rest of the prosecution evidence and the probabilities of the case,

issues.text: whether it would be very unsafe to act on this retracted confession

anchor.surface_text: it would be very unsafe to act on this retracted confession which, according to him, was resiled from as early as an opportunity occurred. Dealing with the first question, he pointed out that the appellant was produced at 3-45 p.m., on June 9, 1956, before the Sub -Magistrate in the court hall which was cleared of all police officials,

issues.text: whether before the Committing Magistrate no question under s. 342 Cr. P. C. was put to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: A complaint is made by the learned counsel that before the Committing Magistrate no question under s. 342 Cr. P. C. was put to the appellant with regard to the confession and, therefore, he had no opportunity to put forward his complaint about the confession until the case came before the Sessions court.

arguments.claim: Confession was not voluntary due to lingering police influence despite clearance of court hall

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the first question, he pointed out that the appellant was produced at 3-45 p.m., on June 9, 1956, before the Sub -Magistrate in the court hall which was cleared of all police officials, and the Jail Warder alone was placed in-charge thereafter the Sub-Magistrate gave the necessary warnings and enough time was given for reflection. The criticism levelled by the appellants counsel is that despite these beneficient actions, still the influence of the police on the appellant still remained

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge accepted the testimony of Natara- jan P. W. 10 , Nachimuthu Goundan P.W. 11 and Subbanna Goundan P.W. 12 with regard to the murders and also that of Munia Goundan P.W. 5

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to appraise oral evidence; rely on confession

holdings.text: The confession was voluntary as the Magistrate conformed to the procedure prescribed by ss. 164 and 364 of the Criminal Procedure Code and the Madras Criminal Rules of Practice.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully gone through the questions put by the Magis- trate, not only on June 9, 1956, when the appellant was given time for reflection, but also on those on June 11, 1956, when he gave the confessional statement, and we are satisfied that nothing could be said against the procedure followed. The learned Magistrate has clearly conformed to the proce- dure prescribed by ss. 164 and 364

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate administered warnings, gave time for reflection, cleared court hall, no material detracting from performance of duty; questions conformed to rules.

holdings.text: There was no inducement or threat by police resulting in involuntary confession.

anchor.surface_text: Further, P.W. 17, the Investi- gating Sub-Inspector, has clearly denied the alleged induce- ment by the police that if be did not confess, others, including his father, would be implicated in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Investigating officer denied threats; appellant's retraction reason false.

holdings.text: Failure to specifically question accused under s.342 CrPC before committing magistrate does not render confession involuntary.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think, granting that the confession was not placed in the fore-front as a piece of evidence against the accused in the Committing Court, such a default if it is one, would in any way show that the confession was involuntary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession exhibited, copies furnished under ss.207A(3),173(4) CrPC; contents known to accused.
No contrary statements to prosecution evidence; absence of elaborate details does not falsify; general trend matches.

holdings.text: A retracted confession requires corroboration as a rule of prudence but general corroboration of its trend is sufficient, unlike accomplice evidence requiring material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: a retracted confession cannot be made solely the basis of conviction unless the same is corroborated... general trend of the confession is substantiated by some evidence... In contrast a retracted confession with the evidence of an approver or an accomplice... standards of corroboration different.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents (Kesava Pillai, Balbir Singh); distinguishes from s.133/114 Evidence Act accomplice rule; retraction reasons false.

holdings.text: Recoveries of bloodstained MO10,11,12 with human blood corroborate the retracted confession.

anchor.surface_text: Agreeing with the High Court that this is corroboration of the confession made by the appel- lant, we are of the opinion that the confession can be acted upon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No satisfactory explanation by appellant for human blood; chemical reports confirm.

holdings.text: Appellant's guilt proved beyond reasonable doubt; conviction and death sentence upheld.

anchor.surface_text: If that is so, the appellants guilt has been proved beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluntary true corroborated retracted confession proves guilt; proceeds without relying on oral evidence.
